etymology_text: From Middle English lyme, lym, lime, from Old English līm, from Proto-Germanic *līmaz. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Liem (“glue”), Dutch lijm, German Leim (“glue”), Danish lim (from Old Norse lím), Latin limus (“mud”).

raw_glosses: (chemistry) Any inorganic material containing calcium, usually calcium oxide (quicklime) or calcium hydroxide (slaked lime).

examples.text: Lime, which is the product of the burning of chalk or limestone, might be bought ready burnt, or it could be burnt in kilns specially constructed in the neighbourhood of the building operations.
examples.ref: 1952, L.F. Salzman, Building in England, page 149.

glosses: Any inorganic material containing calcium, usually calcium oxide (quicklime) or calcium hydroxide (slaked lime).

raw_glosses: (poetic) Any gluey or adhesive substance; something which traps or captures someone; sometimes a synonym for birdlime.

examples.text: Monster, come, put some lime upon your fingers, and away with the rest.
examples.ref: 1610–1611, William Shakespeare, “The Tempest”, in Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies[…] (First Folio), London: […] Isaac Iaggard, and Ed[ward] Blount, published 1623, OCLC 606515358, [Act IV, scene i]

examples.text: Like the lime which foolish birds are caught with.
examples.ref: 1835, William Wordsworth, They called Thee Merry England, in old time [first line of unnamed poem]

glosses: Any gluey or adhesive substance; something which traps or captures someone; sometimes a synonym for birdlime.

examples.text: Sellers moved on until he was actually trusted to operate the limes, the spotlights that can make or destroy an artist's act.
examples.ref: 1980, Peter Evans, Peter Sellers: The Mask Behind the Mask (page 30)

examples.text: Then out of the blue, a spotlight much like the “limes” in a theatre, lit up what seemed like a Punch and Judy tent […] He struggled even more, when from out of the shadows and into the bright light of the limes, stepped Uncle Jolly.
examples.ref: 2018, Robert Charles Hines, Twists and Turns: 13 Tales of the Uneasy (page 121)

head_templates.name: en-verb
head_templates.expansion: lime (third-person singular simple present limes, present participle liming, simple past and past participle limed)

etymology_text: From Middle English lyme, lym, lime, from Old English līm, from Proto-Germanic *līmaz. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Liem (“glue”), Dutch lijm, German Leim (“glue”), Danish lim (from Old Norse lím), Latin limus (“mud”).

raw_glosses: (transitive) To treat with calcium hydroxide or calcium oxide (lime).

examples.text: If I were you, I'd lime.

glosses: To treat with calcium hydroxide or calcium oxide (lime).

examples.text:
URSULA. She's lim'd, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.
HERO. If it prove so, then loving goes by haps:
examples.ref: 1598–1599 (first performance), William Shakespeare, “Much Adoe about Nothing”, in Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies[…] (First Folio), London: […] Isaac Iaggard, and Ed[ward] Blount, published 1623, OCLC 606515358, [Act III, scene i]

examples.text: Abraham, like his parents, seemed to have been limed and caught by the ensnaring inn.
examples.ref: 1891, Thomas Hardy, Tess of the d'Urbervilles, volume 1, London: James R. Osgood, McIlvaine and Co., page 39

etymology_text: Lime (17th c.) and line (16th c.) are alterations of obsolete lind, from Middle English lynde, from Old English lind, from Proto-Germanic *lindijō. The phonetic development is unusual, but it has been suggested that it began in compounds (loss of -d- perhaps before tree, the change to -m- before labials as in bark or wood). Doublet of linden, which see.

raw_glosses: A deciduous tree of the genus Tilia, especially Tilia × europaea; the linden tree.

examples.text: But there was nothing of an ascetic's expression in her bright full eyes, as she looked before her, not consciously seeing, but absorbing into the intensity of her mood, the solemn glory of the afternoon with its long swathes of light between the far-off rows of limes, whose shadows touched each other.
examples.ref: 1871, George Eliot [pseudonym; Mary Ann Evans], chapter III, in Middlemarch: A Study of Provincial Life, volume I, Edinburgh; London: William Blackwood and Sons, OCLC 948783829, book I (Miss Brooke), page 38

glosses: A deciduous tree of the genus Tilia, especially Tilia × europaea; the linden tree.

etymology_text: From French lime, from Spanish lima, from Arabic لِيمَة (līma), from Persian لیمو (līmū). Doublet of lemon.

raw_glosses: Any of several green citrus fruit, somewhat smaller and sharper-tasting than a lemon.
glosses: Any of several green citrus fruit, somewhat smaller and sharper-tasting than a lemon.

translations.word: ក្រូចឆ្មារ

raw_glosses: Any of the trees that bear limes, especially Key lime, Citrus aurantiifolia.
glosses: Any of the trees that bear limes, especially Key lime, Citrus aurantiifolia.

raw_glosses: (uncountable) A brilliant, sometimes yellowish, green colour associated with the fruits of a lime tree.
glosses: A brilliant, sometimes yellowish, green colour associated with the fruits of a lime tree.

raw_glosses: (fandom slang) A fan fiction story which contains sexual references, but stops short of full, explicit descriptions of sexual activity (coined by analogy with lemon).

examples.text: WARNING: This is a lime. While it does not show explicit sex, as a lemon would, references to sexual situations abound.
examples.ref: 8 June 1998, Gary Kleppe, “[Ranma][Fanfic] Tangled Web”, in rec.arts.anime.creative, Usenet

examples.text: Even with all the sex in Garden of EVA, I still think the main stories are better for just being the lemon-scented limes that they are.
examples.ref: 29 December 1998, jiml...@earthlink.net, “[EVA][FanFic][Lemon] Garden of EVA 0:6x - Wet Dreams Bite!”, in rec.arts.anime.creative, Usenet

examples.text: I have no intention of writing any lemon scenes, limes are possibilities but unlikely and if they occur they will be few in number.
examples.ref: 27 November 2001, Schemer, “[Ranma/SF][FanFic] A Learning Experience - Chapter 01”, in rec.arts.anime.creative, Usenet

glosses: A fan fiction story which contains sexual references, but stops short of full, explicit descriptions of sexual activity (coined by analogy with lemon).

etymology_text: From French lime, from Spanish lima, from Arabic لِيمَة (līma), from Persian لیمو (līmū). Doublet of lemon.

raw_glosses: Having the aroma or flavor of lime.
glosses: Having the aroma or flavor of lime.

having the aroma or taste of lime
having the aroma or taste of lime
having the aroma or taste of lime
